awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Collaborative Research: Coding for Green Storage Technologies in Nonvolatile Memories
awd_abstract_narration:
The fast-advancing modern nonvolatile memory technology includes flash memory and phase-change memory as the two most notable representatives. It is critical to create new schemes and architectures to improve their energy efficiency as well as their write speed, reliability and memory longevity. New schemes should fully utilize the unique properties of the memory technologies, including cell programming models, error models and endurance models. The key is to control cell states more flexibly and robustly by closely coupling novel coding schemes with the physics of these memory technologies.

In this project, a novel green storage technology will be developed based on coding theory for nonvolatile memory. The focus will be on flash memory and phase-change memory that share many common features. A new scheme for representing data using relative cell levels will be studied; it optimizes the energy efficiency for both writing and error correction. A novel variable-level cell technology will be developed to maximize storage capacity. New error-correcting codes will be designed to correct memory-specific errors. In addition, new processing techniques will be developed to balance the power consumption at peak and non-peak times. 

The new designs will be integrated to form a comprehensive solution, and their performance will be analyzed thoroughly. The results will contribute to providing a new platform for high-performance ubiquitous computing based on nonvolatile memories.

por.por_cntn:
Nonvolatile memories, including flash memories and emerging phase-change memories, are being ubiquitously used in computer systems. Based on coding theory and information theory, this project has developed storage technologies that improve the energy efficiency, speed, data reliability and memory longevity for nonvolatile memories. They utilize the unique properties of nonvolatile memories, including cell programming models, error models, etc. They control cell states more flexibly and robustly by closely coupling new coding schemes with memories. In particular, the project has explored new data representation schemes based on relative cell levels, which optimize energy efficiency for writing and error correction. New coding schemes have been developed to maximize the storage capacity. New error correcting codes have been designed to improve data reliability, including correcting varied-magnitude errors and cell-level drifting errors. Coding schemes for storing data securely, while still making it efficient and reliable to access and modify data, have been developed. Learning algorithms have been introduced to coding schemes, which has laid a foundation for future nonvolatile storage systems. The new schemes have been rigorously verified in a flash memory testbed using cutting-edge NAND flash memories. It led to collaboration with NASA-JPL, exploring the performance and reliability of flash memories in high radiation environments, which has a potential to impact storage systems in space and defense applications.

Intellectual Merit: This study in this project has led to the development new paradigms for efficient storage in non-volatile memories. New coding schemes called rank modulation based on multi-set permutations have achieved a better balance between the energy efficiency and robustness in cell programming and the storage capacity of nonvolatile memories. New coding schemes based on polar codes have enabled simultaneous support for error correction and local data rewriting with low power consumption. New coding schemes based on coset coding and other techniques have established a coding framework that integrates error correction, data security, data access and replication. New coding schemes that correct asymmetric errors and graded-magnitude errors, which have uniform or non-uniform structures, have made error correction codes better matched to nonvolatile memories. New learning algorithms have been used to improve data reliability. New coding schemes based on Akers array and parallel programming revealed ways to efficiently control memories for both storage and computing. Experiments in cutting-edge flash memory testbeds have verified the potential of the coding schemes for long-term data storage in flash systems.

Broader Impacts: This project has produced new technologies for improving the efficiency of data storage in nonvolatile memories. The results have been disseminated broadly to both the academia ad the industry via scientific publications, seminars and research collaborations, and have led to more research and development on the technologies. The results can lead to better efficiency of various storage, communication and computing systems that are used in many areas. The research has led to curriculum development in new course materials, new projects and research experience for both graduate and undergraduate students, including female and minority students. The project has been used to promote the public awareness to storage technologies, and promote the inter-institutional and international collaboration.
